Bom about 1873, Of peasant origin from the district of Kan-i-Sulaqan near Kazvin. Eor some 5 years a munshi in the Ministry of Public Works at Tehran. Joined the (Swedish) Gendarmerie 1912 sent to Ears. Sultan (captain) in 1914, when he was put in charge of detach ments on Bushire road from Kazerun to Burazjun for some 16 months. A democrat and one of the Tehrani officers whose anti-British machinations led to the incidents of 1915 at Shiraz. Carried on a propaganda of his own among the Khans of the road—Nasr Diwan, Mirza Muhammad Ahan Burazjuni and Shaikh Husain Chahkutahi—which had a great deal to do with their fighting the British in Bushire. Took the British colony from Shiraz as prisoners ta Ahram. His policy was distinctly egoist then (and again in 1923). Left for Isfahan December 1915 : in 1916 was in the exodus of the “ Muhajirin who left the capital to join the Turks and the Germans at Kermanshah and in Turkey, where he remained till 1918. Again joined Gendarmerie 1920, became Officer Commanding Kermanshah, and in that capacity arrested Sarim- ud-Douleh, the Governor (during the Seyyed Zia-ud-Din regime), but showed him great consideration. Entered the new Army of Sardar Sipah 1921, made Colonel (Sarhansr) : Officer Commanding Iraq at Sultanabad, but dismissed from Army by Minister of War for showing incapacity or some 4 arriere-pensee ’ in drawing up plans for the Western Army for which he had been asked. Having asked Sarim-ud-Douleh for a post in January 1923 (through the manoeuvres of Mirza Ali Kazeruni, a former ally in the anti-British campaign in Dashtistan) made Governor of Dashti and Dashtistan. Legation did not approve appointment, the object of which was to promote the schemes of Mirza Ali Kazeruni and the extremist Nationalists in Tehran and Shiraz for the extension of their influence over Dashtistan, and prepare the ground for the return of Mirza Ali to the new Majlis. Made an ally of Shaikh Muhammad Chahkutahi, but his policy set the Khans by the ears, and alienated Ghazanfar-us-Sultaneh of Burazjun, who by a telegraphic understanding with Haji Muin-ut-Tujjar obtained his dismissal by direct order of the Minister of War on the ground of interference in the elec tions July 1923. Returned to Shiraz, where after arrival of Nusrat-ud-Douleh he was employed in reorganisation of Municipality, and appointed Governor of Istahbanat district. Through his methods of canvassing for himself, while at Burazjun and the malpractices of Shaikh Muhammad Chahkutahi and others obtained a majority of the votes in Tangistan and Dashti, and became one of the deputies to the 5th Majlis for Bushire and Dashtistan October 1923. A dangerous intriguer in southern Ears and Ports affairs : hand in glove with Mirza Ali Kazeruni: high in favour with the extremists, and an Anglophobe. 9 Ahmad Khan Qashqai, Sardar Ihtisham Born 1877. Former title, Zaigham-ud-Douleh. Second son of late Darab Khan, Ilbegi of Qashqai (died 1891), but by a daughter of Murad Beg Bahluli, one of the Amaleh and a servant of the Ilbegi. Six months senior to his half-brother, Soulat-ud- Douleh, Sardar Ashair (q. v.), but on account of his mother being of inferiorparentage he has never enjoyed the same esteem in the tribes, left by his father estates at Garmeh in the Sarhad, and in the Garmsir, N T im-deh, Nishun, Bari- khun, Tnng-i-Wardi. Replaced his brother, Sonlat-ud-Douleh, as Ilkhani April 20 th, L907, to June 2nd, 1907, after their respective supporters had fought a small battle at Kudian, when several Khans of note were killed. Appointed Governor of Behbehan June 1908, but attacked and captured on way. Gover nor of Yazd for time in 1911-12. On the breakdown of his brother’s combination with the Governor General, Nizam-us-Sultaneh, in the autumn of 1911, was re-appointed Ilkhani October 14th, 1911—December 7 th, 1912, when boulat-ud-Douleh again displaced him. He was a third time appointed Ilkhani July 5th, 1918, when Soulat-ud-Douleh was attacking the Indian troops and South Persia Rifles in Shiraz, and succeeded in then drawing away from his half-brother most of the clans. He remained Ilkhani till after the departure of l arman Parma, but gradually through rapacity and poor administration lost his following, and on December 17, 1920, the new Go vernor-General, Musaddiq- us-Sultaneh, with local intrigue behind him, brought back Soulat-ud-Douleli in a nominal settlement, by which Nasrullah Khan, 2nd son of Sardar Ihtisbam, was to be Ilbegi. But the last named was soon chased out of the tribe. Since 1920 Sardar Ihtisham has been resident in Shiraz, trying to get the Government to restore his estates seized by Soulat-ud-Douleh : and he keeps a few tents around Marvdasht. Married daughter of Ahmed Khan Shishbuluki : 3 sons, Amir Hussain Khan (q. v.), Nasrullah Khan, Amir Quli Khan. In 1922 in India for medical treatment. In tribal combinations the Kashkuli and half of the Darehshuri clans have generally sided with him. Irresolute, and a poor administrator, but a friendly person. 10 . Ahmad Khan Shishbuluki. November 1920 Governor of Kermanshah and Hamadan: arrested by order of Prime Minister, Sayyid Zia-ud-Din March 1921, and taken to Tehran. Fifth and youngest son ot late Darab n.han, Ilbegi of the Qashqai (died 1894) by a daughter of Murad Beg Bahluli, a servant of Darab Khan : thus full brother to Ahmad Khan, Sardar Ihtisham (q v.) and half-brother to Ismail Khan, Soulat-ud-Douleh. Was a small child when his father died, and thus did not receive similar care and education as his eider brothers, nor was he assigned fair share in the patrimony As result is less cultured and wilder than they, and comparatively poor. Throughout past 18 years of strife between Soulat-ud- Douleh and Sardar Ihtisham has sided with latter. In 1917 took refuge with Bakhtiari Khans, who fixed up arrangement with Soulat-ud-Doulah that Ali Khan should receive 300 Tumans monthly. Soulat-ud-Douleh gave him several thousand Tumans and the command of a body of tribesmen to attack the Indian troops and South Persia Rifles 1918, bat on appointment as Ilbegi by Farman Farma 3 rd July, Ali Khan turned against his half-brother. Owing to his reckless and ruthless plundering of the Qashqai tribesmen, and to his antagonizing Ayaz Kikha Darehshuri (q. v.) by an insult to latter’s daughter, he gradually lost control of the clan 1919-20, and gave up Ilbegisbip September 1920 Remained hostile to Soulat-ud-Douleh in the vicinity of Mayin and Marvdasht with a following which gradually grew smaller in 1921, but was financed by both the Governor-General, JNusrat-us-Sultaneh, and Qawam-ul- Mulk, in order to neutralize and weaken Soulat-ud-Douleh’s power in the tribe. In May 1922, when latter was camped 8 miles from Shiraz, Ali Khan with assistance of some Darehshuri and Kashkuli chiefs suddenly attacked him : casualties both sides. In autumn of 1922 went off to eastern Fars, after his followers had been implicated in several robberies. In 1923 resided in Shiraz,, claiming restoration of his villages seized by his half-brother, but got no redress. Haji Mirza Ja’far Khan, Mubayyin-us-Sultaneh— Born about 1861. Son of Haji Mirza Muhammad Quli Simakani. Was Governor of Behbehan 1911 for short time. Head of Police in Shiraz for some years. Governor of Jahrum 1917-18. Returned from Bombay 1919. Landowner in Simakan district. Connected with Soulat-ud-Douleh and Germans in 1915. Treacherous character. Son Mirza Qasim Khan in 4 Nawaqil ’ branch of Finance Department. 292. Haji Mirza Muhammad Taqi, Fasih-ul-Mulk-— (Poetical name 4 Shurideh ’). Born 1869. Former title ‘ Majd-us-Shuara ’. Son of late Aqa Abtas Shirazi. Is the best known and most literary poet of Shiraz, especially noted for satire. Has considerable knowledge of history and literature. Has as ‘tiyyul ’ village of Burinjun in Kuhmarreh district, granted by 'Nasr-ud-Din Shah. The latter’s brother. Prince Rukn-ud-Douleh, once bastinadoed Fasih-ul-Mulk for a satire. 293 . Hussain Khan, Samsam-i-Nizam- —Born about 1875. Son of Miiza Aqa Kafsh-duz. Factotum of late Ata-ud-Douleh II and present Ata- ud-Douleh III, and acting as their assistant in various governorships.29 k Husain Quh Khan Qashqai, Samsam-us-Sultan —Born aboufc 1876. Son of Must ala Quli Khan (killed by sernmc 188^) who was younger son of Suhrab Khan executed 1873 at Shiraz by Prince Hisam-us-Sultaneh. Married a half-sister of Seulakud-Douleh. Lives with the tribe. 295. Mirza Abdul Husain Khan Shirazi —'Born about 1889. Eldest son of Mirza Muhammad Baqir Khan (q. v.). Educated at American college, Bairut, and speaks English well. Married to daughter of late Mu’tamid Diwan, brother of Asal-nl-MuIk (q v.). By Sari n-ud-Douleh in 1923 made secretary to the Governor-General for foreign affairs, and employment as such continued by Nusrat*ud-DouleK Very friendly and easy to work with. 296. Mirza Abdus Samad Khan ZarqanL—Born about 1890. Son of late Mulla Abullah Eazil Zarqani. Converted to Christianity by G. M. S. Mission in Shiraz 1907, was in danger when taken to Bushire by Sir P. Z. Cox, who put him for a time in the Vice-Consulate as a clerk, then as Munshi to Consulate at Bandar Abbas. Munshi to Shiraz Consulate 1912-16. In 1915 wounded by one of anti-British democrats, who fired at him with intent to kill, lieceived compensation through British Government. After revulsion against proceedings of insurgent gendarmerie officers, acted as agent for Legation till Consulate reopened October 1916. 1917-21 in Einance Department. 1921 transferred to Kerman. 297. Mirza Ahmad Khan, Jalil-us-Sultaneh.— Born about 1885. Son of Khami-Shaukat Shirazi. Head Accountant in the Einance Department, Kerman, 1919-21. Chief revenue officer in Kazarun and Dashtistan 1922. 298. Mirza Ali Khan Ashtiani, Bayan-ul-Mamalik.— Born about 1852. Son of Mirza Baqir, from Siahshan near Ashtian (Tehran). Secretary of late Husain Quli Khan, N'izam-us-Sultaneh, in his governorships of Ears, Arabistan, Khurasan. Accompanied Earman Earma as Chef de Cabinet to Shiraz 1916, and appointed on Prince’s recommendation Director of Einance in Ears, in which post he remained till 1919, when he was dismissed, re appointed about beginning of 1920, and remained till replaced by Mirza Habibullah Khan Aliabadi (q. v.) April 1921. No longer in Einance Department. 299. Mirza Ali Akbar Khan Arsiniani, Muizz-ul-Mulk.— (Poetical name ‘ Shaida ’). Bom about 1873. Son of late Mirza Bahim of the Arsinjan district of Ears : and brother of Banan-ul-Mulk (q. v.). Was in the service of Qawam-ul-Mulk III, as deputy Governor of Darab, Easa : accompanied Qawam- ul-Mulk V to Eastern Ears 1917. Since has resided on family property in Arsinjan. Opium smoker and poet. 300. Mirza Ali Biza Khan Muqtadir Biwan.—-Born about 1878. Younger son of late Mirza Muhammad Ali, Muqtadir Diwan, who was Secretary of Qawam-ubMulk III. Brother of Mirza Eazlullah Khan (Mirza Haji Aqa) who was placed by Qawam-ul-Mulk IV in charge of Khamseh tribes from 1913-19, when he was dismissed. A trader, looted by Gendermerie 1915, in Qawam-ul-Mulk’s service, sent to meet Colonel Gough to Qumisheh 1916 with 100 sowars. In 1919 trading again, and in receipt of a bounty from Qawam-ul* Mulk. 301. Mirza Buzurg (Badi-uz-Zaman) Afkham-us-Sultaneh— Born about 1885. Son of Haji Mirza Sayyid Hasan Mustaufi. In charge of one branch of land taxes paid in Shiraz. 302. Mirza Fathullah Khan, Mu’ayid-us-Sultan.— Born about 1900. Son of Mustashir-us-Sultaneh II (q. v.) of the Qawami family. 303. Mirza Khani. —Born about 1883. Son of Muhammad Ibrahim Khan 4 Arab ’ (of the Mazidi branch of the Khamseh, and of the 4 Amaleh’). Landowner and lessee of various estates of Qawam-ul-Mulk. Member of Shiraz municipality since 1917 election, and elected Vice-President 1923. Married sister of Mirza Eazlullah Khan Banan, Munshi of Consulate. 304. Mirza Masih Khan Burinjuni, Masih-ul-Mamalik, Dr.— Born 1884. Eldest son of late Mirza Ismail Burinjuni, and elder brother, by another mother, of Miiza Ibrahim Khan, Chief Secretary to Qawam-ul-Mnlk y (q. y.). Learnt some medicine under Dr. Carr at Isfahan and since 190876 has practised for himself in Jahrum, Fasa and other parts of Fars. A noted Bahai, and had to flee from Fasa to Shiraz in autumn ^ of 1923 owing to false accusations of being concerned in the burning of a Shiah shrine. 305. Mirza Muhammad Khan I uizz-ul-Mamalik.—Born about 1891- Son of Mugith-ud-Douleh (q. v.) In the Finance Depart iii ent of Fars, and in 1921-22 inspector at Kazarun : for some years in charge of Nizam-us-Sultaneh’s properties in Dashtista^ and Khisht. Now in Shiraz. 306. Mirza Muhammad Hasan Dawa-lurush, Zia-ul-Ashraf— Born about 1877. The principal wholesale chemist in Shiraz. A prominent democrat since 1912. In 1916 arrested in Isfahan by Russian troops, who wanted to shoot him : thanks to intervention of Colonel Gough was handed over to Farman Farn a, who annexed several cases of bis medicines and set him at liberty. 307. Mirza Muhammad Eiza Muharrir, Banan-us-Sharieh.— Born about 1881. A pleader in the ‘Adliyeh’ (court of justice) in Shiraz: and go-between for the Mullas and notables. 308. Mirza Qasim Khan Mugith-ud-Douleh— Born about 1863. Son of Mirza M uhammad Riza, Kadkhuda of the Maidan-i-Shah quarter of Shiraz before 1880. Secretary and factotum of Riza Quli Khan, Nizam-us« Suitaneh (q v.) from before 1900 till 1911, when on the flight of the latter from Fars Mugith-ud- Douleh attached himself to Shaikh Khaz’al, Sardar Aqdas of Muhammerah, where be remained one of the Shaikh’s salaried entourage. Owns the village of Aiguni in Khisht. Suffers from his heart and is feeble. Was in Shiraz where he owns property for summer 1923. 309. Muhammed Ali Khan Shirazi Ahya-us-Sultaneh, Dr —Born about 1889. Son of Mirza Ja’far Hakim-bashi of Prince Zill-us Sultan, in Isfahan about 1895. Has two brothers, Mirza Abdullah Khan and Mirza Abul Qasim Khan, both practising medicine in Shiraz, the second as doctor to the troops, married to niece of Nazim-ul-Mulk. He and his brothers learnt what they know from Dr. Woollatt of the I. E. T. D 1909-21. 310. Sayyid Ali Sarvistani, Mushir-us-Sa’dat — Born about 1859. Son of late Sayyid Hasan Sarvistani. In entourage of Qawam-ul-Mulk : sent as ‘ returning officer ’ for election D 23 to Fasa and Darab and Ear. Rather an intriguing person : anti-Bahai having in past caused deaths of Bahais. 311. Sayyid Asghar Zara' Shirazi, Fakhr-us-Sa’dot— Born about 1871. Son of Mirza Sayyid Ali. Deputy to 1st Majlis for farmers of Shiraz. ‘ Democrat ’ but not much in politics. 312. Savyid Husain Ali, Nasir-us-Sa’dat, Kazaruni— Born about 1879. Son of Sayyid Muhammad Hasau Kazaruni. A farmer in Kazarun district. Formed in Shiiaz 1917 the “ Company Aqdas ” wffiicb became fraudulently bankrupt. In 1916 obtained 20,000 tumans from the S. P. R. for the purchase of corn, which in the end he did not supply : only some 3,000 tomans recovered from him. Meddles in politics of Kazarun and Shiraz, and is a ‘ democrat 313. Sayyid Mustafa Khan ‘ Kasikh ’.—Born about 1886. Of Tehran, where he has been an officer in the Police for a number of years, and latterly in charge of one of the Stations. Appointed Chief of Police at Shiraz August 1923. Brother Sayyid Murtaza Khan, was formerly in (Swedish) gendarmerie, now officer in new army, stationed at Shiraz. Not very capable. 314. Shaikh Ala-ud-Bin, Ala-us-Sharieh —Born about 1899- Younger son of late Imad-us-Sharieh, who was eldest son of Shaikh Yahya» Imam Juma of Shiraz. Brother of Imam-us-Sharieh II (q. v.). XI—liS

physicalDescription.extent: A table of contents can be found at folio 4.An index to the biographies arranged by name can be found at folios 45-48.An index to the biographies arranged by title (and some family names) can be found at folios 49-51.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 54; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. Pagination: the file also contains an original printed pagination sequence.

mods.abstract: The volume contains lists of, and genealogical tables and biographies for, the notable families of Fars [Fārs] and Persian Officials at Shiraz [Shīrāz].The volume includes a 'Sketch Map of Boundaries of Districts of Fars', found in a pocket at the rear of the volume (folio 53).
